facts.text: Income-tax Officer held that the amount represented by the notes was income from undisclosed business activities and was therefore taxable.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal's finding that notes worth Rs. 1,28,000 out of high denomination notes of Rs. 2,68,000 encashed represented concealed profits of the appellant is correct

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from a judgment of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal dated August 7, 1953, filed with have granted under article 136 of the Constitution. The Tribunal held that of the high denomination numberes of the value of Rs. 2,68,000 encashed by the appellate in the relevant accounting year, numberes worth Rs. 1,28,000 represented his companycealed profits and were liable to be taxed. In this appeal the appellant challenges the companyrectness of this finding.

issues.text: Whether on the evidence adduced by the appellant it could be said that the notes were part of the assets received by him from his father

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal had to decide a question which was entirely one of the fact. It had to decide whether on the evidence adduced by the appellant it could be be said that the numberes were part of the assets received by him from his father. The appellants case was this Mohanlal, the appellants adoptive father, was a partner in the firm of Manekchand Tarachand which carried on business in Calcutta.

It came to that companyclusion apparently because the books of account produced did number disclose any source of income.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's rejection of the Ratangarh books of account as not genuine is a reasonably possible view supported by evidence and not unreasonable, warranting no interference.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to say that the reasons given by the Tribunal for the view that the books are not genuine are unfounded or that there was no evidence to support the view that the Tribunal took. In our view, it is possible to find that the Ratangarh books were not genuine for the reasons mentioned by the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's reasons (absence of Calcutta business books, no entry of closure proceeds, suspicious loan entries with note numbers, incomplete record) not unfounded; passes Wednesbury test from Mehta Parikh; SC cannot reappraise evidence.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's finding that Rs. 1,28,000 out of encashed notes represented concealed profits liable to tax is upheld.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from a judgment of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal dated August 7, 1953, filed with leave granted under article 136 of the Constitution. The Tribunal held that of the high denomination notes of the value of Rs. 2,68,000 encashed by the appellant in the relevant accounting year, notes worth Rs. 1,28,000 represented his concealed profits and were liable to be taxed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant failed to prove notes inherited from father due to unreliable books; Tribunal's contrary estimation of possible capital reasonable enough; sufficient to dispose of appeal.

holdings.text: Tribunal's estimation of appellant's uninvested cash at Rs. 1,50,000-2,00,000 (Rs. 1,40,000 max in high denomination notes) from 1926-1945 based on bank interest only may be partly speculative.

anchor.surface_text: the learned counsel for the appellant criticised this part of the Tribunals judgment as based on mere speculation. We cannot help feeling that this criticism may be partly justified but we do not appreciate how it assists the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Books unreliable; no other income shown; large bank balance; but even if speculative, was concession reducing taxable amount and does not undermine main finding on inheritance proof.

holdings.text: Contention that non-resident appellant taxable only on income arisen/accrued in British India cannot be entertained as never raised before lower authorities.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to allow this contention to be raised, for it had never been mentioned at any earlier stage of the proceedings. The learned counsel drew our attention to a portion of the judgment of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner to show that the point had been raised earlier.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No mention earlier; cited AAC judgment portion concerns remittances of Bikaner interest, not these notes; practice bars new points in Supreme Court appeal.

precedents.case_name: Mehta Parikh Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: The Supreme Court would be entitled to intervene in findings of fact by the Tribunal if the fact-finding authority acted without any evidence, upon a view of facts which could not reasonably be entertained, or if the facts found are such that no person acting judicially and properly instructed as to relevant law would have come to the determination
precedents.cited_holding: The companyrt would be entitled to intervene if it appears that the fact finding authority has acted without any evidence or upon a view of the facts, which companyld number reasonably be entertained or the facts found are such that numberperson acting judicially and properly instructed as to the relevant law would have companye to the determination in question.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from a judgment of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal dated August 7, 1953, filed with leave granted under article 136 of the Constitution. The Tribunal held that of the high denomination notes of the value of Rs. 2,68,000 encashed by the appellant in the relevant accounting year, notes worth Rs. 1,28,000 represented his concealed profits and were liable to be taxed.

It is enough to say that the view taken by the Tribunal is a reasonably possible view on the evidence adduced and that it cannot be said that that view is not supported by the evidence or was unreasonable. This would be enough to dispose of the appeal
